quizzes.question: Which three tools are included in the JDK?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Java Development Kit[/h1]

You can run, save, and share your Java codes on our [b]Code Playground[/b], without installing any additional software.
[note]Reference this lesson if you need to install the software on your computer. [/note]
The Java Development Kit ([b]JDK[/b]) is a software development environment for Java applications and applets. It includes:
- The [b]J[/b]ava [b]C[/b]ompiler ([b]javac)[/b]
- The [b]J[/b]ava [b]Ar[/b]chiving Tool ([b]jar)[/b]
- The [b]J[/b]ava [b]D[/b]e[b]b[/b]ugging Tool ([b]jdb)[/b]
- A complete [b]J[/b]ava [b]R[/b]untime [b]E[/b]nvironment [b](JRE[/b]), for running Java programs

After installing the JDK, you will be able to run [b]javac[/b], [b]jar [/b]and [b]jdb[/b] from the Console (Command Prompt in Windows).
[note]JDK is available for free at [b]www.oracle.com [/b]under [b]Java SDKs and Tools -> Java SE[/b].
The upcoming lessons will explain the installation and setup process. [/note]

quizzes.question: You can download the JDK from...
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Installing the JDK[/h1]

[h2]Step 1[/h2]
Go to www.oracle.com > Downloads > Java SE.

[h2]Step 2[/h2]
Click the "[b]Accept License Agreement[/b]" checkbox. 
Choose your platform from the list to download the corresponding installer.[img id="2384" width="100%"]
[note]Once you've downloaded the installer, follow the instructions for installing the JDK on your machine.[/note]

answers.text: Download the JDK from Oracle website
Set the PATH environment to variable
Test the installation while running javac from the command line

quizzes.question: Rearrange the following steps in the correct order for successful Java installation.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]JDK & PATH[/h1]

On Windows, the [b]JDK [/b]will be installed by default in the directory "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.8.0_xx" with the latest upgrade number indicated by xx. [b]JRE [/b]defaults to "C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.8.0_xx". 
Open the [b]JDK[/b] folder, open the bin folder, and copy the [b]path[/b], which you will need to use in the next step. [img id="2390" width="100%"]
For the JDK to work, you need to add its path to the PATH environment variable. To do that, right click on My Computer and go to Properties > Advanced system settings.
Switch to the Advanced tab > Environment Variables and click on [b]New [/b]button if PATH does not exist in the list. If PATH already exists, select it and click [b]Edit[/b].[img id="2389" width="100%"]
Add the copied path value to the variable.
You should see something like this when adding the PATH: [img id="2391" width="100%"]
[note]If the PATH variable already exists, just add the value to it, and then separate it from the other values with a semicolon.
Do NOT delete any existing entries; otherwise, some existing applications may not work properly.[/note]
Save the changes. 
To verify that JDK is properly installed, open the Command Prompt, type in [b]javac[/b], and press Enter. (You have to re-open the Command Prompt so the new PATH variable is recognized).
If the JDK has been successfully installed, you will see something similar to the screen below: [img id="2392" width="100%"]
The latest installers add the PATH variable to your system automatically.
Our tutorial shows the installation in Windows, but the javac command works on all supported platforms.
[note]You can run, save, and share your Java codes on our [b]Code Playground[/b], without installing any additional software.
Reference this lesson if you need to install the software on your computer. [/note]
